Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides scholarships to able and financially needy upper-division students majoring in all STEM fields. The project emphasizes supporting students from groups that are underrepresented in STEM disciplines. A primary goal is to ensure such students graduate in five years with a minimum of student debt. This is done through a combination of individual counseling, tutoring, group seminars, internships, and research experiences. All this takes place within strong cohorts of students with similar experiences and goals. Additional goals include improving student placement after graduation and increasing the number of students going to graduate school in STEM disciplines.

Intellectual Merit: The academic programs into which the students go are strong, and there are academic support activities. The project emphasizes placing students within local industry and in retaining contact with these students. These goals are pursued though a combination of industry presentations, internships, seminars on applying to graduate programs, and comprehensive, convenient exit surveys. The S-STEM project has considerable support within local industry. It also exploits the natural cohorts that have been formed under the aegis of the MemphiSTEP program.

Broader Impact: The project is increasing the number and diversity of students who complete a STEM major and go on to work in the field or to further education. It specifically targets students from populations underrepresented in science and first-generation college students. The project emphasizes employing local talent that serves to enrich both the individual students and the local community.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Scholarships in STEM project Supporting a New Generation ran at the University of Memphis from Fall 2012- Spring 2017. During that period, it supported 71 financially needy STEM students across all the STEM disciplines.

The Ethnicity of our recipients was as follows:

Ethnicity

Asian

8

11%

Black or African American

13

18%

White

34

48%

Not Reported or Unknown Race

16

23%

Establishing the racial diversity of the recipients is not possible as 23% of the recipients elected not to declare a race.

However, we can say that the S-STEM recipients contained a greater percentage of females than the majors from which they were drawn. 

Gender

    

Female

27

38%

Male

44

62%

The distribution of awards across the STEM majors was as follows:

Intended Major Freq. Percent
Biology 9 12.68
Chemistry 6 8.45
Computer Science 5 7.04
Geosciences 5 7.04
Mathematical Sciences 6 8.45
Physics 6 8.45
Engineering - Biomedical 6 8.45
Engineering - Civil 8 11.27
Engineering - Computer 5 7.04
Engineering - Electrical 5 7.04
Engineering - Mechanical 3 4.23
Engineering - Technology 7 9.86
Total 71 100

 

As can be seen the S-STEM project tried to support students equitable across the majors. Quite a number of students had multiple majors, this table shows only their "primary" major. 

The project involved recipients with other students and faculty in their discipline through networking meetings, connected recipients with existing academic support at the university, provided targeted academic support via tutoring, and provided support through a professional counselor. Recipients agreed to a mid-semester evaluation by all their professors.

The project was successful with only one of the 71 recipients unlikely to graduate and only two students who left the project. During the project 61 students graduated, two left the project, and eight were in good academic standing when the project ended. Of the eight students in good academic standing four graduated at the end of Summer 2017, two are approved to graduate at the end of Fall 2017, and two have filed intent to graduate at the end of Spring 2018. Of the two who left the project, one subsequently returned to the University, and is expected to graduate at the end of Summer 2018. Of the 61 students that graduated during the project 58 are currently employed in a STEM field or are pursuing further STEM education (we include the medical field in STEM).

Important lessons were learned about academic support for upper division STEM courses that has permanently altered the way that learning support is provided at the University of Memphis. An Engineering tutoring service begun under the S-STEM project is now permanent and supported by the Herff College of Engineering.  

Our mid-semester evaluations were a qualified success. Response rate was 62% overall and 74% when reminders were sent. Over the course of the project the evaluations identified 56 potential concerns. Of these 46 were resolved and recipients passed the courses, in eight cases students failed the course, and in two cases the student dropped the course. Unfortunately, the DFW rate, the percentage of students that received a D or F grade or who withdrew from the course, amongst courses for which we received a response was 3.9% while the DFW rate amongst those course for which we did not receive a response was 6.4%. There was also a small number of course that for various reasons were not evaluated (including some online courses offered at other institutions) and the DFW rate for this small group of courses was 14.3%. We have learned important lessons about how to conduct such evaluations and these have been codified in an article submitted for publication. 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2017
Modified by: Alistair J Windsor
